content.description: Approximately 40' left of "Bad Mamajama'.  The leftmost of two parallel cracks leading to a roof.  Anchors below the roof.  Climb a short hand crack through a wide pod to the chains above.  Short but sweet!  Crux is the last 10 feet.
content.location: About 40' left of 'Bad Mamajama'.

content.description: 90ft of stellar, vertical to slightly overhanging face and arete climbing. High endurance route with small holds and multiple technical cruxes.
content.location: Route is 30' to the right of butterfly buddies crack. Route is east facing starts on right hand side arete continuing up into the face

content.description: Thin fingers/tips up a left facing dihedral to a roof. Feet are the crux, find pods for fatter fingers!
content.protection: Doubles .3-1" Offset nuts and nuts, slings for the roof.
content.location: 30' left of Bad Mamajama, the rightmost of 2 parallel cracks leading to a roof. There are chain anchors to the right, rap from here or continue up to "Bond Street" to belay/climb "If Only We Could"

content.description:
The obvious splitter crack with a big roof a third of the way up. The route was initially climbed by Chad Suchoski who aided the roof section. Alex Voboril and Chris Herle later cleaned large amounts of loose shale and greenery from the lower section and added a few bolts to make it a well protected lead. Chris was the first to free the route in it's entirety.

Pitch 1: Clip a bolt from the tree, and then pull a few moves to get established before clipping another bolt that protects a strenuous move through the section of smooth rock above (falling here is safe, but would get you well acquainted with the tree). Follow the lieback crack to the roof, traverse left, clip a bolt in the roof (extend to prevent rope drag) and then fight your way through the roof on good hand jams. Continue to the anchor. 11b.

Pitch 2: Follow the sustained crack, using a variety of crack techniques. Finish on a nice ledge with bolts/rap rings. 10d.

Descent: Need a 70m to rappel the route. In order to reach the the pitch 1 anchor you must kick off of the rock on the way down or you'll be left hanging in space (not good). Another option would be to walk to the left side of the crag and rappel another route.
content.protection: Singles BD .3-.5, doubles .75-3. Extra in the hand sizes might be useful for the long second pitch.
content.location: Obvious crack to the right of the large alcove on the right side of the crag.

content.description: 95 feet of beautiful face and arete climbing. First set of anchors are just after cruxy section about 50' up. The second anchors go all the way up 13 bolts to the top! Perfect lead for those working this grade. Tightly bolted fun!
content.location: In treed covered section of crag just to the right of Butterfly Buddies. Route starts using butterfly buddies crack for first 10 ft. Bolts start low right of crack. Use steep arete to get up to gradually sloping face.

content.description: Climb the sustained finger crack to the chains above.  The finger locks on this climb are stellar.  There is one dirty section where some rock was removed; in this section the face holds are excellent.
content.protection: Gear to 0.5, this crack takes nuts well.
content.location: See Crag Map in "photos"

content.description: Stellar route, 60' of 5.11- climbing up a steep to overhanging face using liebacks and face holds. 60' up you get a bomber jug but very little rest then comes the 20 feet of hard overhanging face climbing. 3 back to back cruxes up the overhang to mussey hooks
content.location: Just left of Butterfly Buddies and Tiger Moth. Vertical face that waves up to a steep overhang. Start is on terraced hill

content.description: Jugs leads to a few arete moves back to the face allows you to clip the chains. Uncharacteristic holds for the Mills. Crux near the top. First bolt is a spinner, which will be fixed soon, but shouldn't deter you from climbing this route. Would be a classic if it was 80 feet.
content.protection: 5 bolts and anchors, probably could have been 4.
content.location: Right of Tiger Moth under the broken roof

content.description: Excellent route, quality crux section from bolts 3-5.
content.location: To the left up the short hill next to butterfly buddies and sting like a bee. Start is on a large flat rock/ perfect belay ledge

content.description: Head up the slabby groove towards big features moving through 2-3 bluges/steep sections. Crux is towards the top on kind of awkward off balancing moves, transitioning onto the large side pull jugs. Harder than it looks.
content.location: The face to the left of Bad Mamajama. start by manteling right of the tree or in between.

content.description: Climb the left side of the face to a slab/crack above, move left under the small roof, then climb the knife edge arête to the anchors above.
content.protection: Bolts.  Stick clip the first bolt.
content.location: See Crag Map in "photos"

climbs.name: Megalodon
climbs.fa: 1st Pitch Adam Scardaci, 2nd Pitch Chad Suchoski

content.description: Climb the hand crack using occasional face holds. The crack becomes off width about 30' up. Use the main crack and the smaller one to your right.  At 50' you will arrive at a set of anchors. You can stop here (5.9) or continue another 65' through multiple flaring offwidth roofs (5.10c)
content.protection: Gear to 5" Bring at least doubles .75" to 4"
content.location: Once at the top of the hill on the approach take the trail to the right. Climb is in about 150' See Crag Map in "photos"

content.description: Thin face climbing above a crenulated protuberance. Two distinct cruxes, both involving balancy feet with thin gastons.
content.protection: Climb and set top rope from the chains of 'Yes You Can'. It is possible to go up the bat cave and set the rope by rapping from the top of 'If Only We Could'.
content.location: The face between 'Yes You Can' and 'When We Can'. Rap from chains for 'Yes You Can'.

content.description: Climb the crack and face features up to the clean finger crack system and move to the anchors above. A must climb!
content.location: See Crag Map in "photos"

content.description: Move up a wide crack to a 15' horizontal roof about 15' off the deck.  Crest the lip and climb the fractured crack system to the chain anchors above.
content.protection: Gear from BD #0.75-#6.  Heavier on the large gear.
content.location: See Crag Map under "Photos".

content.description: Route starts just above the top of 'When We Can' at "Bond Street". Starts with a sweet hand crack, leading to a roof and an overhanging wall above. The overhanging face of the perched boulder above is protected by two bolts.  Chain Anchors are located at the lip
content.location: 30' left of 'Bad Mamajama'.  This is the second pitch of 'When We Can', belay from 'Bond Street'.

content.description: Large corner crack. Climbs to same anchors as this my jam. Cold air flows out of the base of this crack. Great refrigerator in the summertime!
content.location: Just right of 'This is my Jam'.  Shares anchors.

content.description: Start by climbing up a vertical seam which switches from right facing to left facing about 30ft up. Climb this vertical seam past a short broken section to a large ledge. Traverse the ledge to the right until you reach the edge of a large gully. Instead of heading into the gully, climb up a short face section to a 3" crack in a bulge. After the bulge, follow a splitter .75" to 1" crack which heads up a very exposed steep ramp to the anchors.
content.location: About 15 feet right of Megalodon starting in an obvious vertical crack system.

content.description:
Fun chimney and offwidth climb with many face options. Pitches can easily be linked if you have the gear for it.

P1: Climb the chimney and go left at the death block (don't worry its solid). Continue through a bulge with glorious face holds and then either build an anchor or traverse right to a nearby bolted anchor.

P2. Go up the slightly overhanging offwidth section with a couple mandatory offwidth moves, great exposure! Continue to the bolted anchor above.

Rappel down and right to the aforementioned bolted anchor midway up the wall.
content.protection: Cams BD .75 - 6. Bolted anchors with quick links.
content.location: Starts to the left of Calcite Cringe. Look for a chimney that splits at a large block wedged in the crack.

content.description: Start up a wide chimney which makes you start to wonder what you got yourself into. Then traverse around a corner to the left and begin climbing easier terrain with some gnarly jams up a very steep to overhanging wall. More offwidth brings you to some ass puckering exposure and stemming through a bulge to the top. A two bolt anchor awaits at the top. Two 60m ropes are required to rappel to the ground.
content.protection: Cams double rack to 4". Single 5" and 6". Nuts, 1 set.
content.location: To the far Left of Brutal Truth

content.description: Great mill crack! medium to large crack with big liebacks and face holds.
content.location:
At the top of initial crag trail hill climb take the main trail to the left along the base of the crag. After about 150 yards the trail goes into the shade of some big trees. a large overhang will be on your right. Keep going into the treed area about 50'. There will be a terraced hill the route is at the base. Its is a the long right facing crack. Go up the steep face as it gradually slopes to less vertical. Shares anchors with obvious 10b sport route "Tiger Moth" which follows arete and face just to the right of the crack

See "Crag Map"in photos for further details

content.description:
Start in a short thin seam to a small blocky area with a decent rest. Now pay penance to the cryptic onslaught above in a vertical dance of masochistic stratagem, clinging to hope, inch by inch, struggling upward, learning what it means to bleed!

Pitch 2 is a 5.10 crack which takes gear to 3"
content.location: Bolted route between Calcite Cringe and Brutal Truth.

content.description:
Start by climbing up a short easy section of fingers and hands which quickly opens up to a wide offwidth. Now get in there and start groveling, milking what face holds you can to a small roof which you climb around to the right. Above lies yet, more offwidth until you can exit on small face holds which lead to a nice belay ledge. Its recommended to belay here unless you want to take doubles in 4",5", and 6" cams. The belay takes 3" to 4" gear. 100ft.

Pitch two climbs up more offwidth utilizing a whole new series of choice words to a big sandy ledge where you can build another anchor. The anchor takes 5" gear and some smaller finger to off hand size pieces. Its kinda janky up there, so saving that #5 for the anchor is recommended. 50ft.

A short scramble leads to the top.
content.protection: Cams, single from .3" to 2". Double 3", 4", 5", and 6".
content.location: Far around the corner to the left of "This is my Jam". A big ol obvious offwidth with a small roof a quarter of the way up.

content.description:
Start by climbing a thin splitter crack and gain a foothold on the more featured face above. Work your way up making a short traverse left across the face passing a bolt and gain the vertical crack above. Follow the crack to a two bolt anchor above. 90ft.

Pitch 2 follows a crack through a short wide section and up under a roof. Clip a bolt and exit the roof directly to a wildly exposed face which has a splitter crack and swallows gear. A two bolt anchor with rap rings awaits above.
content.location: Just to the right of Bleed.

content.description: Climb the chimney to the small exit portal above.  No protection exists for this route.  To descend, down climb the chimney.  If you are lucky, you may spot a bat or two in the back end of the cave.  If you wish to find a way to the top side of the crag, this is an easy way up.  A short 4th class scramble exists above the chimney before the hiking commences.
content.location: See Crag Map in "photos"

content.description: Climb the left corner crack over a couple of bulges to the anchors above.
content.location: See Crag Map in "photos"
